questiontext.text: Random variable XX is normally distributed with mean μ=290\mu = 290 and standard deviation σ=100\sigma = 100. X=N(290,100)X = \text{N}(290,\,100) Evaluate P(|X−290|>30)P\left(\big|X-290\big| > 30\right). In other words, what is the probability that XX is outside ±30\pm30 units from the mean?

generalfeedback.text:
First, draw a sketch. We can label the XX axis by adding integer multiples of 100 to 290. We know to shade the two tails because values far from 290 satisfy the condition |X−290|>30\big|X-290\big| > 30. We draw the boundaries at 290−30=260290-30=260 and 290+30=320290+30=320 because those are the solutions to |X−290|=30\big|X-290\big| = 30. We can also rephrase the probability.

P(|X−290|>30)=P(X<260 OR X>320)P\left(\big|X-290\big| > 30\right) ~=~ P\big(X<260 \text{ OR } X>320\big)


We calculate the zz values of the boundaries. Left boundary: z1=260−290100=−30100=−0.3\begin{aligned} z_1 &= \frac{260-290}{100} \\\\ &= \frac{-30}{100} \\\\ &= -0.3 \end{aligned}

Right boundary:

z2=320−290100=30100=0.3\begin{aligned} z_2 &= \frac{320-290}{100} \\\\ &= \frac{30}{100} \\\\ &= 0.3 \end{aligned}

We have rephrased our problem into a standard normal probability problem, because

P(|X−290|>30)=P(|Z|>0.3)P\left(\big|X-290\big| > 30\right) ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big|>0.3\right)

So, we just need to evaluate P(|Z|>0.3)P(|Z|>0.3). I will also point out that 30100=0.3\frac{30}{100} = 0.3. In general, if XX is normally distributed, then: P(|X−μ|>d)=P(|Z|>dσ)P\left(\big|X-\mu\big|>d\right) ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big| > \frac{d}{\sigma}\right)

From here we have a formula that lets us use the zz table. (We practiced this part before.) P(|Z|>0.3)=2−2×P(Z<0.3)=2−2×0.6179=0.7642\begin{aligned} P(|Z|>0.3) &= 2- 2 \times P(Z<0.3) \\ &= 2 - 2 \times 0.6179 \\ &= 0.7642 \end{aligned}

P(|E−20|>9)=P(E<11 OR E>29)P\left(\big|E-20\big| > 9\right) ~=~ P\big(E<11 \text{ OR } E>29\big)
